name: NPR
text: Administrators at Brigham Young University's campus say they are "deeply troubled" by reports that students may have intentionally tried to contract COVID-19, lured by blood donation centers that are paying a premium for plasma with COVID-19 antibodies. https://t.co/SNmIF5v2Ed

name: NPR
text:
Portugal's forward Cristiano Ronaldo, one of the world's most famous athletes, tested positive for the coronavirus. He "is doing well, without symptoms, and in isolation," the country's soccer federation said.
https://t.co/QTZwIzsYZT

name: NPR
text:
More than $1 billion has now been spent on TV ads for the 2020 presidential election in just 13 states — with most of that money being spent by Biden's campaign and groups supporting him.

Here's a state-by-state breakdown.
https://t.co/LVj8zNXhGF

name: NPR
text:
The no compromise movement didn't begin with the Dorr brothers. Our reporters track the tangled history of the message. 

This weeks episode looks at the intersection of racism and the no-compromise gun rights movement. https://t.co/q5ujEednQH

name: NPR
text:
Apple has announced the iPhone 12 — the first 5G-enabled iPhone that will eventually let data flow at speeds 10 to 20 times faster than 4G. But 5G infrastructure is years away from being widely available.
https://t.co/KL795UDCTu

name: NPR
text:
Amy Coney Barrett declined to address whether she believes President Trump can pardon himself, calling it a matter that could come before the Supreme Court after she is confirmed.
https://t.co/J8uDJT98rY

name: NPR
text:
Amy Coney Barrett says she considers Brown v. Board of Education a "super-precedent" — those cases "so well settled that no political actors and no people seriously push for their overruling."

She does not consider Roe v. Wade to be among them.
https://t.co/hAkVuJaxj8

name: NPR
text:
Delta reported $5.4 billion in losses in the third quarter of this year — bringing its total pandemic losses to more than $11 billion. A spike in virus cases after July 4 had a chilling effect on travel demand.
https://t.co/1KrOUqOma0

name: NPR
text:
With 3 weeks left in the presidential race, Joe Biden and President Trump are heavily courting senior citizens — a crucial voting bloc that has been disproportionately affected by the pandemic.
https://t.co/E1q2RA9H3L

name: NPR
text: President Trump, said Biden, "would love nothing better than to fight about whether or not I would in fact pack the court or not pack the court." https://t.co/7ehyinNwqh

name: NPR
text:
"The more that I thought about the way that we wage war in the 21st century, the more it seemed...insufficient to just talk about one theater of conflict," Phil Klay says of his new book.

"I wanted to talk about the ways these wars bleed into each other." https://t.co/pHWmrAXurv

name: NPR
text: Spike Lee's shrewdly observant camera meshes perfectly with David Byrne's layered and rousing sense of musical theater in "American Utopia," says reviewer John Powers. https://t.co/cJywTuIbMn

name: NPR
text:
A new report finds that the number of Americans dying from COVID-19 since early May is on average 50% higher than 18 other high-income countries, adjusting for population size.

"The United States really has done remarkably badly."
https://t.co/0MJagAa0oS

name: NPR
text:
Outdated efforts for preventing fraud in state unemployment systems are hurting millions of people with legitimate claims, by building up lengthy and unnecessary delays — while not actually managing to catch much fraud.
https://t.co/kpF7zjE3E8

name: NPR
text:
Last week, President Trump tweeted that troops "should" be home from Afghanistan by Christmas.

In an interview with NPR, Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Mark Milley said no final decisions have been made.
https://t.co/2b2UgvicAk

name: NPR
text:
The Senate Judiciary Committee is holding its third day of hearings on President Trump's nomination of Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court.
https://t.co/xUkHLqStci

name: NPR
text: ●Every day NPR reporters around the world bring you the news you need to make informed decisions. Support the critical journalism on which you and millions of others rely with a donation to your local NPR station today.  https://t.co/DMfnsOb6OZ https://t.co/sNgojP2VhK

name: NPR
text:
Voters in Virginia will now be able to register until 11:59 p.m. on Thursday — in person or online.

A federal judge extended the deadline after the Department of Elections website was down for hours on Tuesday.
https://t.co/hs18dx3CCo

name: NPR
text: Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett said she doesn't consider Roe v. Wade as "super-precedent" — saying "that doesn't mean that Roe should be overruled, but descriptively it does mean that it's not a case that everyone has accepted." https://t.co/WptxWTep2Z

name: NPR
text:
The white teenager accused of fatally shooting two demonstrators and injuring a third in Wisconsin in August will not be charged with gun crimes in his home state, an Illinois state prosecutor announced.
https://t.co/15xySgfWXI

name: NPR
text:
The St. Louis couple who waved guns at Black Lives Matter protesters marching through their gated community in June have pleaded not guilty to two felony charges.

A grand jury indicted the couple last week.
https://t.co/InV5taCur5

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: NEW: Barron Trump, the 14-year-old son of President Trump and Melania Trump, also tested positive for the coronavirus, but showed no symptoms, the first lady said.

The first lady said both she and her son have since tested negative for the virus.NEW: Barron Trump, the 14-year-old son of President Trump and Melania Trump, also tested positive for the coronavir… https://t.co/miSmBbKyjj

name: NPR
text:
Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee continued to question Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett on her views about the Affordable Care Act — and Barrett continued to avoid stating them.
https://t.co/XtbNuK7T4M

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRGoatsandSoda: How have women from Wuhan, China, the former epicenter of the coronavirus crisis, been faring over the past few months?

We spoke to three women from the capital of central China's Hubei province to see how they've been coping with the pandemic. 
https://t.co/YYgBxiaHah

name: NPR
text:
A Wisconsin judge has temporarily blocked an emergency order by Gov. Tony Evers' administration to limit the capacity of bars, restaurants and other indoor public spaces.

The state saw record numbers of both coronavirus infections and deaths on Tuesday.
https://t.co/W0kuz1tHEi

name: NPR
text: RT @NPRWeekend: As Election Day approaches, how have your conversations with those across the political aisle changed? Have you recently had a tense encounter with someone who holds different political beliefs? Email us at weekend@npr.org and we may share your thoughts on the radio!As Election Day approaches, how have your conversations with those across the political aisle changed? Have you rec… https://t.co/32Tif9qpxy

name: NPR
text:
Most of the country lets election officials do the arduous process of opening and sorting absentee ballots long before Election Day.

In Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, they have to wait.
https://t.co/YkYRsVENmM
